data.title: It looks like that Ubisoft intends to release games on Steam roughly year after initial release
data.meta_description: Steam page for Settlers just popped up on Steam and that was first Ubisoft game released in 2023 (February 17th on PC, July 4th on streaming services and...
data.text:
dex3108

Oct 26, 2017

23,507

Mar 9, 2024

#1

Steam page for Settlers just popped up on Steam and that was first Ubisoft game released in 2023 (February 17th on PC, July 4th on streaming services and consoles.

View: https://store.steampowered.com/app/2750080/The_Settlers_New_Allies/

So i guess they intend to keep their games exclusive to Ubisoft Connect/Epic Store roughly a year.

Charamiwa

Oct 25, 2017

6,157

Mar 9, 2024

I'm impressed they've stuck to their guns for so long. Feels like they're the only big publishers not reverting back to Steam completely. Or maybe they've signed a deal with Epic that prevents them to do it.

So i guess they intend to keep their games exclusive to Ubisoft Connect/Epic Store roughly a year.

It's been like that for a couple of years now I think.

Those dumbasses still refuse to implement achievements for their steam releases.

The games are still being launched through their Connect launcher/store and that one has its own achievements.

dex3108

Oct 26, 2017

23,507

Mar 9, 2024

#10

It's been like that for a couple of years now I think.

We technically didn't know. They did big dump of their games on Steam last year or in 2022 then went silent. They never said anything about future games. This is their first new game after that big dump. If this fall we get Motostorm and Mirage then we will know for sure that it is year of exclusivity.

dgrdsv

Oct 25, 2017

12,470

Mar 9, 2024

#11

We technically didn't know. They did big dump of their games on Steam last year or in 2022 then went silent. They never said anything about future games. This is their first new game after that big dump. If this fall we get Motostorm and Mirage then we will know for sure that it is year of exclusivity.

The "big dump" you're referring to was their decision to "come back" to Steam in 2019.

After that the releases were a fairly stable stream although I don't know if there is/was any sort of a "fixed timed exclusivity" between Connect and Steam there. Feel free to check by release dates: https://store.steampowered.com/publisher/ubisoft/#browse

10,157

Mar 9, 2024

#13

That's fine. I can wait and once it's been a year, it'll be a wait for 75% off, if I don't forget about the game first. No biggie :)

Oct 27, 2017

2,738

Mar 9, 2024

#15

It makes no sense. I can understand for larger games, since they don't want to split the revenue, even though I think the PR and large player base Steam provides far makes up for it. But for smaller games like Prince of Persia, Settlers etc, they're just hurting the games for no reason other than some stupid principle.

c0Zm1c

Oct 25, 2017

3,229

Mar 9, 2024

#18

The "big dump" you're referring to was their decision to "come back" to Steam in 2019.

After that the releases were a fairly stable stream although I don't know if there is/was any sort of a "fixed timed exclusivity" between Connect and Steam there. Feel free to check by release dates: https://store.steampowered.com/publisher/ubisoft/#browse

2019 was when they claimed Steam's business model is "unrealistic" though, with 2022 being when they reversed that decision.

Steam's Business Model Is "Unrealistic," Ubisoft Executive Says

Ubisoft executive Chris Early, who is the VP for partnerships and revenue at the Assassin's Creed company, has spoken up to share his thoughts on Steam. Speaking to The New York Times, Early said the company's business model, as it stands today, is unworkable. "It's unrealistic, the current...

Ubisoft is officially coming back to Steam, starting with Assassin's Creed Valhalla

https://www.eurogamer.net/assassins-creed-valhalla-headed-to-steam You can't beat him https://media.giphy.com/media/lV7WTpkkUyPjG/giphy.gif

Mar 9, 2024

#19

I play like one Ubi game each year or one every other year. A FarCry game or something like Avatar: Frontiers of Pandora.

I just buy a cheap key and play through Connect. It works well enough.

If games link to an external launcher anyway, I'm not fussed about not having it on Steam.

Well, the only year which saw nothing from Ubi on Steam was 2021.

Only three games released in 2020 on that list. Perhaps those releases were locked in before making the decision to leave Steam? Though I doubt it given they were all mid to late 2020. Ubisoft is kind of fickle when it comes to releasing on Steam!

Mar 9, 2024

#26

I play like one Ubi game each year or one every other year. A FarCry game or something like Avatar: Frontiers of Pandora.

I just buy a cheap key and play through Connect. It works well enough.

If games link to an external launcher anyway, I'm not fussed about not having it on Steam.

This is my strategy too. Storefront loyalty is so dumb and waste of time. It's crazy some people want essentially double DRM and Gaben to get that extra 30% cut so they can have some petty features.

Last edited: Mar 9, 2024

Oct 28, 2017

2,513

Mar 9, 2024

#27

Do those games still require UbiConnect? If yes, they can keep them forever.

Exactly my problem, you're buying a shortcut on Steam essentially with these games with other launchers.

If it's not a native steam port, it's likely cheaper and less complicated to just buy direct on the launcher they were originally made for.

jetsetrez

Oct 27, 2017

2,050

Mar 9, 2024

#28

Then I will consider buying them roughly a year and two months after they release (for them to get put on the platform I want to use and for them to be discounted, because I'm not going to wait all that time and still give them their full asking price).

Thankfully Ubisoft very rarely makes anything I find remotely appealing anymore, but I would've bought the new Price of Persia if it were on Steam, and I'd probably be interested in whatever Splinter Cell they're working on. But if they want to treat me like a second class customer I will treat their products like second tier games not deserving of full price.

While I'd love everything from everyone Day 1 on Steam , Ubi isn't a huge loss for me. If it isn't Splinter Cell, Far Cry 2 style Far Cry or maybe The Division, I probably wouldn't play it until a deep, deep discount years down the line anyway(if at all). We'll see about Outlaws.

I would, however, pony up the $15 for Ubisoft+ for any of those at launch, so their release strategy is working as intended. Idk, though, $70 upfront sounds better to me than a month sub + discounted sale a year or more after release. .

#48

There's little point to buying them on Steam if they're still going to launch through Ubisoft Connect.

Guides and in-launcher/in-game message boards are pretty big reasons, especially on a Steam Deck where you can get even more by slapping in a browser and shortcuts to outside sites. Not everyone plays at a desk and not everyone -- me, this part is me since I'm exclusively in BPM when I play games -- wants to alt-tab all the time once they're in game mode.
